Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation2: Meeting the customer for handing over a package
Story: I stared at my phone, the group chat buzzing with messages from my stepbrother and mom. “Don’t forget, we’re leaving for the cabin at noon!” my mom reminded me. It was our first holiday together as a blended family, and I knew how much it meant to her that I join in, to show I was really part of this new family. But as I zipped up my delivery jacket, my work phone pinged—a last-minute delivery, and the address was across town. The customer had already called twice, sounding impatient. My manager’s voice echoed in my head: “Always be on time, always be polite. Our reputation depends on it.” I could picture my family waiting, the car packed, my absence a silent disappointment. At the same time, I imagined the customer, checking the clock, ready to complain if I was late or curt. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations—be the reliable step-sibling or the professional delivery person. I stood frozen in the hallway, keys in one hand, phone in the other, torn between two worlds that both needed me right now.
